reviewText: The second half of the stunning Full Metal Alchemist: Brotherhood anime, and it does not disappoint.  Caught in the conspiracy created by the evil homunculus Father, the Elrics and their allies begin the dangerous task of fighting against Father's cruel plans for the Amestrians.  The animation is gorgeous, the fights are intense, and the story amazing.  If you liked the first anime, you're sure to love this one.

reviewText: Don't read the Amazon editorial review if you haven't seen this - it contains MASSIVE spoilers on this series, including the culmination of Mustang's vengeance, and the ending of the series.  Shame on you Amazon!!!I recently purchased this collection for $29.99 (thank you Funimation!).  This is the second half of Fullmetal Alchemist Brotherhood.  FMA Brotherhood is the second FMA series, and the one that follows the manga more closely.  In the first half, there were some changes from the manga just so that there wasn't too much overlap (the original series was being released while the manga was running and it caught up and passed the manga and therefore had a very different direction after about episode 15 or 20).(This review assumes you have watched the first half)This half covers episodes 34 to 64, starting with the arc in Briggs.  May and Marcoh have discovered the nation wide transmutation circle while Scar and Kimblee head north as well.  Ed and Al are 'guests' of Olivia Armstrong at the Briggs Fortress.  Their quest takes a different approach in this half, less on the journey for the Philosopher's Stone, focused more on their attempts to free the nation from the grip of the homonculi and Father (who they met up with earlier in the series).  The second half of the series follows the manga so exactly, that there are even lines exactly from the manga.  I read the manga after watching this series, then re-watched and it's remarkable.Hiromu Arakawa is a talented female manga author, and she has done her due diligence in researching the background required for this series.  For the Ishvalan War she actually even interviewed WW2 vets.  Her story telling is magnificent.  This series is all about friendship and unity.  A common theme to Japanese manga and anime (like a lot of the war anime that are inherently anti-war).  The characters may be rather over the top in many cases, but they are so interesting and likable that the viewer just can't stop watching.I prefer the Japanese audio track.  Romi Park (a Korean / Japanese voice actress) is masterful as Edward Elric.  The supporting cast is very well matched with their characters.  I especially enjoyed Olivia's very gruff voice actress, and Wrath and Greed are both cast well also.  Some of the humor is much more apparent with the subtle Japanese voice inflections as well.  Many times this doesn't come across on the English language dub.  But this is one of the better dubs, just comparing one of the better English dubs to quite possibly the best Japanese original voice cast is incredibly tough.  A lot of the Japanese (and American for the dub) voice actors reprise roles from the original series.The Blu-Ray is incredible.  Playing it side by side next to the DVD version (thanks to my local library), you really see a difference.  The audio is also amazing.  One little weird thing: switching to the Japanese audio while watching requires pulling up the pop-up menu rather than just flicking the audio button on my PS3 remote.  It's one of the only Blu-Rays that does it that way.  But you don't have to set the English captions, once you hit Japanese 2.0 audio the English captions are automatically activated.  The American dub is in 5.1 surround.This is an amazing series.  I firmly believe that this is the best anime release this year.  FMA Brotherhood on Blu-Ray is amazing, and I waited to purchase the series until the Complete Collections were released, rather than buying the 5 individual release sets at $25 - $35 each.  For $30 each ($60 total) you get 64 episodes of one of the greatest anime series of all time.  I love you Funimation!  Now just finish D-Gray Man!

reviewText: The second part of Brotherhood was ok. They give you more players and action but also a lot of fillers as well. A lot of the new people who are here are a waste. The main fight at the end was not great. The 2 brothers bond is still good and the way it ended was cool. This one followed the Manga but it was not great like the last one. The last one had more emotional stuff and had a better story. This one had better art work and was flashy. A good pickup if you like Full Metal but the first one was way better!

reviewText: Before you buy, keep in mind! If you think this will be like the original, think again- aside from integral places, integral characters from the original series, and the focus of the brothers Elric to get their bodies back, it goes in an entirely different direction.That first half of the series got me laughing (had to get my jaw wired back on) and crying (I think my tear ducts are officially empty now). This half gets a lot darker. Like The Girl With The Dragon Tattoo-gone-animated dark. Correction, no hardcore swearing or sexual themes, but it does get pretty graphic in the violence and themes. Including the ancient concept of becoming like God. Or rather, like a god. And the steps taken to get there are unbelievably intense and foreboding.The animation in this far supercedes the original series, the plotline gets more intricate and deeper, and the characters (at least the main integral characters from the original, which means not Rose, nor Olivier) get deeper personalities.Towards the end, things got so intense in a lot of firefights (sorry, Roy Mustang!) and the disturbing techniques used for them, it got me tearing up at how even a good soldier can be driven to be nearly a monster, and not only proverbially.If there were anything I didn't really like, it'd be a few seconds during the fight between Scar and Wrath where it looked like the animation had been hastily drawn rather than thought out. Aside from that, this was immensely better than the original series and worth every penny and then some.

Even my brother, who is not really a fan of anime, enjoyed watching this series from start to finish.Watch it, own it, love it.

reviewText: FMA Brotherhood is different from the 1st FMA series. I have have been told that it follows the manga closer than the 1st series. I don't know if that's true or not, and it really doesn't matter. It is essentially the same premise as the 1st series, but with a few plot alterations. The main differences lie with the characters. Some of the old characters were different. For example: Ed and Al's Mom didn't become a homunculous. Their Dad had a completely different back story. There was also a new homunculous, who shall remain nameless. Lust also played a minor role in this series; which was kind of surnprising.On the heroes side Major Armstrong has a sister. General Armstrong. She's even more hard than the Major. Her subordinates also played a crucial role in the story and were all pretty cool as well. One of the main plots of the story was a couple siblings from a foreign country that were competing for the right to become emperor. The main thing that bugged me about Brotherhood was the replacement voice actor for Scar. The new guy is good, but it's strange to hear a different voice coming out of a character that I liked so much.Even though it's different I really like Brotherhood. It is really cool. If you like the original you'll like this version as well.
